title: 111_hr1943
content: The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" is the short title of the Act. It includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with subsection (f) of section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amended to add new paragraphs for such adjustments. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with subsection (f) of section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 amended to add new paragraphs for such adjustments. The rate table for any taxable year shall be further adjusted as provided in subparagraph (B) by multiplying the minimum and maximum dollar amounts for each rate bracket by the applicable multiplier. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The rate table for any taxable year is adjusted by multiplying the minimum and maximum dollar amounts for each rate bracket by the applicable multiplier based on the individual's primary place of abode. The rate applicable to any bracket shall not be changed. The tax rate brackets are adjusted based on the individual's primary place of abode. The tax amount is adjusted to reflect these changes, and any amount not a multiple of $50 is rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The Secretary determines multipliers for each statistical area of the United States annually to apply to taxable years. The Secretary determines annual multipliers for each statistical area in the United States for taxable years, based on cost-of-living differentials. The Secretary determines annual multipliers for each statistical area in the United States for taxable years based on cost-of-living differentials. The applicable multiplier for each statistical area varies depending on the cost-of-living differential for the calendar year. The cost-of-living multiplier for statistical areas is based on the cost-of-living differential for the calendar year. The cost-of-living multiplier for statistical areas is determined by dividing the cost-of-living for the area by the average cost-of-living for the United States. The Secretary of Labor calculates and publishes a cost-of-living index for each statistical area annually. The Secretary of Labor determines and publishes a cost-of-living index for each statistical area based on average market prices for the area for the 12-month period ending on August 31 of each calendar year. The cost-of-living index is determined by the Secretary of Labor for each statistical area based on average market prices for the 12-month period ending on August 31 of each calendar year, using the same methodology as the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers. The term 'statistical area' refers to any metropolitan statistical area. The cost-of-living index is determined by the Secretary of Labor for each statistical area, including metropolitan statistical areas. The area applicable multiplier for any area outside the United States is 1. The amendment applies to taxable years after December 31, 2009, with a transition rule for 2010.
